title: 108_s2584
content: The Act is titled the "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" and introduces a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" offers a 50% credit on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. The maximum credit for eligible persons is $30,000 per year. The credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities under the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 is limited to $30,000 per year, reduced by creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments refer to qualified investments made by the eligible person in the entity for property placed in service. The credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities under the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 is limited to $30,000 per year, reduced by creditable investments in the entity. This reduction includes qualified investments made by the person in the entity for property previously placed in service. The limit for the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 is $30,000 per year for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. Qualified value-added agricultural property includes items used to add value to goods derived from organic matter. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 allows for a tax credit on qualified value-added agricultural property owned and operated by eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. Eligible persons are those who materially participate in an eligible farming business. The tax credit under the Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 applies to eligible farming businesses that are not passive activities. Determinations for corporations, cooperatives, partnerships, estates, or trusts are made at the shareholder, partner, or beneficial interests level. Farmer-owned entities include corporations and S corporations. Entities eligible for the tax credit include corporations, partnerships, and cooperatives where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or interests. Entities eligible for the tax credit include corporations, partnerships, and cooperatives where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or interests. Constructive ownership rules apply, with family members defined as spouse, children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. For tax purposes, a child legally adopted or placed with the taxpayer for adoption is treated as a child by blood. Qualified investments refer to cash payments for purchasing equity in a farmer-owned entity, specifically stock in a domestic corporation acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. The text chunk discusses the acquisition of capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, and patronage interest in a cooperative between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, for tax purposes. Special rules apply for married individuals filing separate returns. For married individuals filing separate returns, the credit amount is reduced to $15,000 instead of $30,000. Rules for allocation of credit in estates and trusts apply, along with restrictions on certain ineligible property. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by the credit amount allowed and any recapture under subsection (e). Rules similar to section 50(a) apply for recapture if qualified agricultural property is disposed of or no longer qualifies within 5 years of being placed in service. The section outlines special rules in the event of death for eligible persons, suspending the period for 2 years after the person's death. Heirs who are also eligible persons may not be subject to certain transfer rules. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations, and the section does not apply to certain property placements. The section outlines special rules for eligible persons in case of death, suspending the period for 2 years after death. Heirs who are also eligible persons may be exempt from certain transfer rules. The Secretary will prescribe regulations, and the section does not apply to property placed after December 31, 2010. Amendments are made to the general business credit and minimum tax credit. The text chunk discusses amendments related to the value-added agricultural property credit in the tax code. It includes changes to the general business credit and minimum tax credit. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding the value-added agricultural property credit. This includes changes to the general business credit and minimum tax credit, with specific provisions related to the carryback of the credit and deduction for certain unused business credits. Basis adjustment is also addressed in the amendments. Basis adjustment is amended in the tax code to include payments related to credits allowed under section 38. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified investments in value-added agricultural property made after December 31, 2004.
